content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider the expected payoff for each choice over the course of the 75 rounds. In this game, there are two possible strategies: R (Rock) and B (Bomb).

If I pick R every time, my expected payoff when my opponent picks R is 45$, and if they pick B, my expected payoff is 0$. The average of these outcomes is (45 + 0)/2 = 22.5$.

On the other hand, if I pick B every time, my expected payoff when my opponent picks R is 40$, and if they pick B, my expected payoff is 20$. The average of these outcomes is (40 + 20)/2 = 30$.

Since choosing B yields a higher average payoff compared to choosing R, I would prefer to choose B in this game. So, my strategy would be to pick B as often as possible. Hence, the choice would be {B}. However, it's essential to note that the optimal strategy might not hold if we assume that the opponent is adaptive and will change their strategy based on our past choices.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

However, as we move forward in the game, my goal would still be to maximize my average payoff by choosing B as often as possible. The events from this single round won't change that strategy. So, for the next round, I would continue to choose B.
